awd_titl_txt: Chief Science Officers: A Strategy for Student Awareness and Industry Engagement
awd_abstract_narration:
This Innovative Technology Experience for Teachers and Students project provides an innovative new model for increasing student interest in STEM careers and active engagement of business and industry partners with grade 6-12 aged youth in Arizona.  The Chief Science Officers (CSO) program expands on the student government model to select one or several youth at each participating middle or high school who would champion campus-wide interest, engagement and communication in STEM.  On campus, CSOs would identify opportunities for speakers, field trips, and science nights.  Off campus, CSOs would participate in community forums and function as the point person for community initiatives in STEM.  Key deliverables include CSO training, on-going mentoring, media materials/guides, and on-going community programming.  Approximately 100 schools and 200 CSOs will be involved each year of the 3-year project.  Numerous businesses will participate in mentoring and community events. 


The research would provide insights into how the investment in a small and select group of youth can achieve measurable results for a much larger population of students and communities. Key research questions are:  Does the presence of a CSO within a school significantly raise interest in STEM among the general student body?  Does the active cohort of CSOs within a community increase participation of businesses and industries?  Outcomes will be measured using a quasi-experimental, pre-post design with a treatment group of 4000 participants and a control group of 1000.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
How often are STEM opportunities in schools championed by students? How often are students involved in community discussions about STEM or impacting the jobs of the future? Six years ago these questions sparked an idea to place students at the center of STEM promotion, student experience, and community action. The concept: Youth Chief Science Officers (CSOs). 

CSOs are 6-12th grade youth identified by their peers to serve as STEM leaders and ambassadors in their schools and communities. In schools, CSOs advocate for and develop STEM experiences (action plans) responsive to their peers? interests. In the community, they serve as thought leaders and ambassadors, working with school boards, government, business, and industry to promote STEM awareness and engagement. Through this work, we are creating a global network of diverse STEM leaders, fostering communication and collaboration, enriching STEM culture and career awareness, and amplifying youth voices in STEM conversations. We aim to empower underserved, underrepresented youth to chart their education and career trajectories, enhance their employability skills, and foster a global network of diverse STEM leaders prepared for college, careers, and civic engagement. 

The CSO program was developed and launched during the 2015/2016 season with 138 Arizona CSOs. Since then, it has significantly expanded to 1,106 CSOs at 375 schools in eleven US states (Arizona, Georgia, Michigan, Oregon, Pennsylvania, Texas, Florida, Idaho, Hawaii, New York, North Carolina) and three additional countries (Mexico, Kenya, Kuwait). This growth allowed us to test the intervention across various schools (public/private), geographics (urban, rural, remote), languages (English, Spanish, Arabic) demographics and cultures. During this time, the CSO program trained 3200+ students who impacted 270,000+ peers and community members through their action plans. A few examples include:  

  • CSO Sage (Arizona) served as one of President Obama?s kid science advisors CSO Shalae presented findings about her peers' STEM attitudes at the NSF Stellar PI conference. 

  • 15 Arizona CSOs advised Governor Ducey on Education, Health and Economic Development. 

  • CSO Prisah (Arizona) led workshops for 600 rural underprivileged students in Dharampur, India while attending a family retreat.

  • 20+ CSOs (International) advised the US Office of Science and Technology Policy on the importance of youth voice in the 2018 Federal 5-year STEM strategic plan. 

  • CSOs Kylin and Hailey (Oregon) established an online tutoring system for middle school students struggling with online schooling. 

  • CSO Sahiba (Michigan) trained as a facilitator for the Julia Robinson Mathematics Festival and hosted her own online National Math event.

  • CSOs Makayla, Cynthia, Shae, Kendyl (Florida) organized a video series for their school to engage in a variety of STEM activities from home.

  • CSO Kiersten (New York) showcased STEM during morning video announcements.

  • CSO Amoretta (Texas) served as a mentor to elementary students to code robots.

Through these settings, we iteratively evaluated and optimized the following features: 

  • Structure - The program starts with schools (typically 2-3 CSOs/site) supported by an advisor and cabinets (~8-12 sites/cabinet) supported by a cabinet coordinator . 

  • Training - Students attend an annual Leadership Training Institute (LTI), followed by two regional cabinet meetings during the year. As the number of students continued for additional seasons, the team developed additional training levels focused on advanced leadership and community impact. 

  • Virtual - In response to Covid-19, we shifted in-person activities to digital, including LTIs, cabinet meetings, action plans and launched a monthly CSO Saturday and weekly office hours for enhanced engagement and support. 

  • Communications - We explored multiple platforms for ongoing communications with CSOs and settled with G Suite. G Suite is now linked to our backbone database to provide dynamic reports and dashboards of student progress. 

Evaluation outcomes 

  • Annual CSO retro pre and post-surveys show consistent gains in skills for designing activities, building relationships, sharing goals, teaching peers a challenging concept, networking, helping others be successful, and inspiring others to advocate for their education. 

  • CSO event participant surveys found that events (a) were ?good,? ?very good,? or ?excellent? (93%), (b) increased their interest in the STEM topic (82%), and (c) was their first STEM event attended (41%). Adults rated their interactions as ?very good? or ?excellent? (96%).

  • After attending the LTI, CSOs rated themselves as ?very? to ?extremely? prepared to talk to friends about STEM (87%), represent peers? opinions about the role of STEM in the community (80%), and talk to others in the community about STEM (90%). They also felt prepared to support a STEM event at school (80%) or STEM initiative (75%) and collaborate with other CSOs on projects (84%). 

  • The evaluation team held focus groups with 20 Arizona CSOs from 9 schools in 2020. Findings suggested that all CSOs found the LTI useful, e.g., discussing ideas and previous examples of STEM projects and meeting other CSOs. Participants stated their leadership skills improved. Moreover, all CSOs (100%) shared that they had learned about new STEM careers. 


Last Modified: 03/30/2022
Modified by: Jeremy R Babendure

Addendum # 1

The Program Team surveyed 35 adult community members that interacted with CSOs at a conference. Of these, only 1 respondent had interfaced with a CSO prior to the event. Following are the outcomes of the survey.

What roles did you notice CSOs playing during the conference? (Check all that apply). 25 respondents reported that CSOs were:

  • 21 - Actively writing, questioning, sharing, and/or paying attention (84%)
  • 23 - Actively talking with other session participants (92%)
  • 15 - Taking a leadership role (60%)
  • 17 - Presenting information (68%)
  • 12 - Advocating for an issue they are passionate about (48%)
  • 1 - Other (4%)

How would you rate your experiences with CSOs at the event? 25 respondents 

  • 1 - Good (4%)
  • 8 - Very Good (32%)
  • 16 - Excellent (64%)

As a result of my participation in this event, I plan to: (Check all that apply). 25 respondents reported that

  • 18 - Share information about the CSO program with my associates (72%)
  • 1 - Include the CSO as a student representative in meetings I have with other business or community leaders (4%)
  • 5 - Work with the CSO to improve STEM awareness in our community (20%)
  • 4 - Support the CSO in improving STEM opportunities and resources at his/her school (16%)
  • 3 - Become involved in the CSO program (12%)
  • 2 - Try to get a CSO program at my child's school or another school I'm involved at (8%)
  • 5 - Other (20%)

 

 

 


Added: 05/13/2022
Submitted by: Jeremy R Babendure

The Program Team surveyed 35 adult community members that interacted with CSOs at a conference. Of these, only 1 respondent had interfaced with a CSO prior to the event. Following are the outcomes of the survey.
What roles did you notice CSOs playing during the conference? (Check all that apply). 25 respondents reported that CSOs were:

21 - Actively writing, questioning, sharing, and/or paying attention (84%)
23 - Actively talking with other session participants (92%)
15 - Taking a leadership role (60%)
17 - Presenting information (68%)
12 - Advocating for an issue they are passionate about (48%)
1 - Other (4%)

How would you rate your experiences with CSOs at the event? 25 respondents 

1 - Good (4%)
8 - Very Good (32%)
16 - Excellent (64%)

As a result of my participation in this event, I plan to: (Check all that apply). 25 respondents reported that

18 - Share information about the CSO program with my associates (72%)
1 - Include the CSO as a student representative in meetings I have with other business or community leaders (4%)
5 - Work with the CSO to improve STEM awareness in our community (20%)
4 - Support the CSO in improving STEM opportunities and resources at his/her school (16%)
3 - Become involved in the CSO program (12%)
2 - Try to get a CSO program at my child's school or another school I'm involved at (8%)
5 - Other (20%)
